data.text: Bike Touring Medicine Cabinet
What type of ‚Äúmedicine cabinet‚Äù do you take with you? What types of medicine, bandages, etc? What do you tried to be prepared for?
I'm sure if you search this group there will be posts covering this topic.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: Definitely Neosporin, band aids, a patch of non stick gauze, medical tape, and an ace bandage (latter is nice for making big bandages, and for wrapping joints). Other suggestions: tweezers (or some sort of little multi-tool that can do a similar job) chap stick, cough drops, gloves. Something for sunburn might help but I think it's better to plan ahead and not get burned in the first place.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: A few blister bandaids, regular bandaids and some Tylenol. That‚Äôs all for me.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Depends where you are. In Australia a bandage for snake bite and know how to use it. I've always carried a broad spectrum antibiotic in remote areas, though never needed to use it. I also carry homeopathic arnica and lavender oil.
data.author: Alison Wheeler

data.text:
Do some research at CrazyGuyOnABike.com you will find lots of answers there. Depends on where and how remote the touring is. In the USA, there are hospitals and care facilities easily found. Sunscreen, bug repellant, stuff to treat minor scrapes, cuts, burns, tylenol, anti-diarrheal, knife with tweezers, things like that.
crazyguyonabike.com: Bicycle Touring: A place for bicycle tourists and their journals
crazyguyonabike.com
data.author: Jonathan Harman

data.text: Tweezers are underrated imo
data.author: Andy Decker

data.text: Never leave home without Benadryl. Plus all the other stuff mentioned. And a space blanket.
data.author: Susan Kopczynski Jostrom

data.text: I quit hauling first aid because I NEVER use it. I do carry and use, ibuprofen, lotion, floss, and electrolytes but that's about as close as I get.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Broad spectrum antibiotics, plastic skin, bandaids. Probiotics, antiseptic cream. Poo stopper, insect bite relief, crepe bandage
data.author: Vicky Cowan

data.text: My prescription meds, ibuprofen, triple antibiotic cream or ointment, hydrocortisone cream or ointment, and a tube of Valtorin. Buy the house brand and save money. If I can talk my doctor into it I like to carry a Zpack (Zithromax). It's a 3 day course of upper respiratory medication. For a first aid kit, an assortment of Band-aids, 4√ó4 gauze pads, paper tape, and a 4 inch ace wrap. I just use soap and water to clean cuts and abrasions. I also like to carry a triangular bandage.
data.author: Tony Rice

data.text: I kinda have 2 kits. One for day rides, and one packed for the longer tour I am waiting the do. The second one is also a repair kit for tent, bags, etc. Day kit, band-aids, sun screen, mozzy repelant, mozzy bite balm, ibuprofen, bum cream, intiseptic cream. Tour kit. Way to much and I will have to rationalize it. But additional items included are: Iodine, alcohol wipes, a couple of gauzes, Ace bandage, a couple of cotton swabs, tweezers, tick remover, mirror, water treatment tabs, plastic glove, space blanket, neosporin cream, a couple of Amoxicillin tablets, The country where I am currently has more pharmacies than convenience stores (literally) and I would find one and be able to top up or add anything as needed in almost any village. The other thing I have found useful is that even things like Amoxillin are over the counter meds here. The list above reminds me I need to buy poop tablets.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: never thought of it, but mirror is a good addition.
data.author: Peter Thelibrarian

data.text: Yes, I got one of those little metal survival mirrors, the size of a credit card. Good for inspecting areas I cannot see directly (ticks and bites), or popping zits, or signalling in an emergency (highly unlikely I know).
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Irish Whiskey
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: Benadryl, because I‚Äôm allergic to poison ivy and cedar trees and it works wonders to stop the itch. It helps with mosquito bites, too. Migraine medicine, since I‚Äôm prone to migraines. Some Aleve and Excedrine for various aches and pains. A couple bandanas that also serve as potholders and sweat wipes and washcloths and whatever else I need them for. That‚Äôs about it.
data.author: Michele Bernhard

data.text: use an anti-wet bag, the types of medicine are body pain medicine, fever medicine, handiplast plaster, blood booster, cold medicine, antibiotics, commonly used medicines, muscle cramps medicine, high blood pressure medicine, sufficient cash and vitamins üòÅüôè
data.author: Agus Sopiandimac Indra Kesumah

data.text: black electrical tape and toilet paper, if you need anything else you need a hospital.
data.author: Steven Hawkswell

data.text: I'm a retired EMT and search and rescue worker so I started off by carrying a lot of stuff. Over the years I have pared it down and carry the following: - one roll of 1/2" tape - one roll of 1" gauze - A couple of 2"X2" gauze pads - Meds (Naproxin, after-bite, benedryl, peto-bismal tablets). - a couple of wipes (packaged in foil and great for cleaning road rash).
data.author: David Rubin

data.text: Tweezers (part of my multiplier tool) aspirin, duct tape (wrapped around CO2 cartridges) a couple gauze bandages and Tegaderm.
data.author: PS Collins

data.text: Pain relief, chamois cream, mole skin, sun screen
data.author: Jenn Bakker
